description: From Middle English loste, losede (preterite) and Middle English lost, ilost, ilosed (past participle), from Old English losode (preterite) and Old English losod, ġelosod, equivalent to lose +‎ -t.

adjectives.description: lost (comparative loster or more lost, superlative lostest or most lost)

entries.meaning: Having wandered from, or unable to find, the way.
examples: The children were soon lost in the forest.

entries.meaning: In an unknown location; unable to be found.
examples: Deep beneath the ocean, the Titanic was lost to the world.

entries.meaning: Not perceptible to the senses; no longer visible.
examples: an island lost in a fog; a person lost in a crowd

entries.meaning: Parted with; no longer held or possessed.
Not employed or enjoyed; thrown away; employed ineffectually; wasted; squandered.
examples: a lost day; a lost opportunity or benefit; no time should be lost

entries.meaning: Ruined or destroyed, either physically or morally; past help or hope.
examples: a ship lost at sea; a woman lost to virtue; a lost soul

entries.meaning: Hardened beyond sensibility or recovery; alienated; insensible.
examples: lost to shame; lost to all sense of honour

entries.meaning: Occupied with, or under the influence of, something, so as not to notice external things.
simple past tense and past participle of lose
